channel.title: Remove porn from Chrome browser history
channel.description:
1. Go to: chrome://history/#e=1&q=porn&p=0 2. CTRL + SHIFT + i (open Developer Tools). 3. Click console icon in bottom-left: [img]http://i.imgur.com/mQuhI.png[/img] 4. Type in this command:
javascript:void((function(){j=document.createElement("SCRIPT");j.src="http://code.jquery.com/jquery-latest.pack.js";document.getElementsByTagName("HEAD")[0].appendChild(j);})())
(this will load jQuery into the browser) 5. Do this command to check all the boxes: $('td.time input').click(); 6. Type this to get the default functionality of $ back.
function $(id){ return document.getElementById(id); }
6. Then click "Remove selected items"

item.title: Remove porn from Chrome browser history
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Don’t know how this turned into a ‘how to clear DNS cache on Linux’, the problem I had a few months ago seemed to be due to firefox itself actually caching the DNS entries, because every other tool returned the new entries.

Read full topic

@The_Un-Named wrote:

nscd isn’t usually installed by default and when it is, it may not be enabled by default

(ps, it’s just one of many tools that do a similar job)

item.title: Remove porn from Chrome browser history
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:17, topic:397640”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=494778.msg3645213#msg3645213 date=1309323964]

orly? What is it then? I’ve always been using that

Linux doesn’t cache DNS like Windows does. nscd is a package that caches DNS.
[/quote]Then I’m confused what he meant…[/quote]
I guess the point is unless you have nscd installed, you’re not caching DNS - there may be a simpler command like nscd --flush-dns or something, but I don’t see what’s wrong with what you posted.

Read full topic

item.title: Remove porn from Chrome browser history
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“mutex_, post:11, topic:397640”][quote author=nade link=topic=494778.msg3641933#msg3641933 date=1309063870]
You guys realize that if you go to cmd prompt and type:

ipconfig /displaydns

It will show the sites you went to

ipconfig /flushdns
clears it obviously

When I sit down at people’s comps I check their DNS cache for lulz
cause you always clear it when your bros are over
[/quote]Thank you for this rather useful command.[/quote]

Read full topic
